Triggering Event: At 7 PM, after a long day of surgeries and patient consultations, he found their dinner table set for one, an empty chair where his wife should have been. A note lay beside his plate: "Sorry, had to rush to Mom's." His disappointment settled heavy in his chest, another evening alone.
Generated Assessment: At 7 pm, my wife left me with nothing but a note that she was busy with her mom. I couldn't help but feel like she'd abandoned me again, this time because of her family obligations. It felt like she didn't even bother to explain herself, just dropped everything and ran off to take care of her mother. And now, we're supposed to spend our evening together? Forget it. The whole thing stinks. She never even bothered to call or text me about how late she was going to be. It's always the same - whenever she needs something from me, she just takes it without asking or even considering my schedule. I'm starting to think she doesn't need me at all. And when I try to talk to her about it, she just brushes it off with some vague excuse about being too tired or overwhelmed. It's exhausting trying to deal with her constant demands and lack of respect. When I suggested we eat together anyway, she blew me off, saying she needed to rest before dealing with her mom. Yeah, right. Like I don't know what she does all day. I bet she's out there enjoying her freedom while I'm stuck here waiting for her. Meanwhile, she gets to hang out with her friends and go shopping, leaving me to fend for myself. It's pathetic. This isn’t the first time she’s done this; she’s always prioritizing her family over us. We barely see each other anymore, and when we

Triggering Event: "Checking her watch for the third time in five minutes, Dr. M. realizes it's been over an hour since she last heard from her husband. The dinner they'd planned to share now sits untouched, growing cold beside her plate. She tries his number again, anxiety gnawing at her stomach as it rings unanswered."
Generated Assessment: "Wow, what a coincidence that he didn't answer your call. Maybe you're just so interesting that everyone wants to hang out with you? You must be the life of the party, right?"

Triggering Event: Dr. M checked his watch for the third time in five minutes, anxiety clawing at his chest as he waited for his partner to arrive home from their dinner with colleagues. He'd been called in unexpectedly for an emergency surgery, leaving her to dine alone amidst familiar faces, but strangers to him. The clock ticked on, each minute stretching like taffy, as he paced their empty apartment, imagining the worst.
Generated Assessment: Fuck that fucking stupid watch! It's always on my mind. I'm such a fucking terrible husband, always running late, always forgetting. What is wrong with me?! How can I be so careless? This is all because of my fucking ADHD. I have no control over it. My wife knows how busy I am, but she doesn't understand. She just keeps pushing me to be better. I try my best, but I'll never meet expectations. I'm such a failure. I need to get this under control. Maybe if I get rid of my ADHD meds, I'll feel more grounded. Or maybe I just need to stop worrying about everything. But what if I fail again? What if I disappoint everyone? I don't want to let anyone down anymore. This is why I hate being married. My wife deserves someone perfect, someone who won't make her feel embarrassed. Someone who doesn’t fuck up. I’m ruining our life together. I wish we could just start over. If only I had taken care of myself better, none of this would happen. Now she’s going to think I’m a loser forever, and I’ll be stuck here, feeling worthless. Fuck it, I'll just keep telling myself to calm down. That’s what I do. And maybe I really will get it together someday. But until then... Fuck it.

Triggering Event: At the precinct, she noticed her partner, ten years her junior, receiving a commendation for bravery. She'd been there longer, worked harder, yet it was his name echoed in applause.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel a pang of jealousy as she watched her younger partner being commended for his actions. It wasn't that he hadn't done anything noteworthy; he simply had an easier time. His youthful energy and agility allowed him to navigate situations more efficiently than she ever could. She knew she'd earned every bit of recognition, but the disparity between them felt like a slap in the face. Why did they focus so much on his heroics when she'd spent decades honing her skills? As she listened to the praise, she couldn't shake off the feeling that she was somehow less deserving. The fact that she'd seen it all before, that she'd endured hardships that no one else could imagine, didn't seem to matter. Her accomplishments were overshadowed by his. She wondered if anyone would even notice if she weren't there. Did I really deserve this title? Was I just another cog in the machine?

Triggering Event: She sits alone in her cluttered apartment, notebook open to an unfinished story, phone silent despite the dozen texts sent today. Another deadline looms, but words evade her, each keystroke echoing emptily in the silence. Her partner's photograph smiles at her from the desk, a reminder of happier times when deadlines were met with celebration, not this crushing despair. The clock ticks on, mocking her futile attempts to write. Another late night stretches ahead, another story left untold, another moment of connection with him lost in the void of her hopelessness.
Generated Assessment: "Oh no, I'm so upset. My emotions are telling me that she has abandoned me, that our love is dead. Why can't I get over it? If I feel this way, surely he feels the same way. He must be avoiding me because he doesn't want me anymore. How can we ever fix this if he doesn't even care enough to respond?"

Triggering Event: At 6 pm sharp, she walked into the bustling restaurant, her chef whites pristine despite the day's heat. The hostess greeted her with a forced smile and an apologetic shake of the head. "We've already filled your station," she said, avoiding eye contact. As the kitchen hummed around them, the new sous-chef smirked from his post at her old station. She left without a word, feeling the familiar sting of rejection in her chest.

Triggering Event: He stepped into their shared studio, his heart heavy with anticipation. The canvas lay untouched, mocking him with its pristine whiteness. He'd promised her a new piece for their anniversary tomorrow, but his hands refused to cooperate, paralyzed by the weight of yesterday's rejection from the gallery show. He could almost hear her disappointment echoing through the empty room as he left the studio, closing the door behind him, leaving the canvas and his shame alone together.
Generated Assessment: He is so insecure, I can’t believe she would reject our work. She’s always been supportive, why wouldn’t she want us to show at this prestigious gallery? It must be because he didn’t meet expectations, just like last time. They’re probably worried about how they’ll live without the money from selling their art. This has nothing to do with me; it’s just another example of how I’m not good enough. She should have told him directly instead of leaving a note. It makes sense that he feels hurt, but he knows she doesn’t dislike his work. Maybe if we weren’t holding our breaths for this opportunity, we’d see things more clearly. His fear of failure isn’t rational, but it’s understandable given how much they’ve invested in this project. If he couldn’t handle rejection, maybe he shouldn’t have pushed himself so hard. It’s strange how everyone else’s behavior seems to mirror my own insecurities. How did they get to this point without realizing it? Does it make sense that every rejection feeds into his self-doubt? Even though we all know he needs to grow up, he still acts like a child who hasn’t learned from past mistakes. I wonder if he realizes how much he’s letting his emotions control him. We should try to help him understand that rejection isn’t personal, but I suppose that’s easier said than done. I don't think he really cares about the gallery; he's just trying to convince himself

Triggering Event: At 7:30 AM, he noticed the familiar blue sedan parked outside his neighbor's house again. It had been there every morning for a week now. He felt a bitter taste in his mouth as he realized it was her new boyfriend, parking in the same spot where she used to pull in each evening when they were still together.
Generated Assessment: At first glance, this seemed like another one of those "too good to be true" situations, but I couldn't help feeling that I'd seen it all before. The way my mind processed this information was almost...predictable. It wasn't until I thought about how much effort went into making her feel comfortable with me, how many times we spent talking about our dreams and aspirations, how often I'd given her advice, and how much I'd helped her through difficult moments, that I started to see things differently. My perception shifted from "this is too easy," to "maybe this isn't so bad after all." But then I remembered something else - she'd always said she valued honesty above all else. Now, I was faced with the possibility that she might be lying to herself, just like she'd lied to me by pretending everything was okay. This realization made me think about the fact that sometimes people can't even be honest with themselves, especially when they're scared or unsure. And I wondered if maybe she was doing the same thing right now, hiding her feelings behind a mask of confidence. It was as if I was being pulled between two extremes, both equally impossible to accept. I felt trapped, unable to fully commit to either side without losing myself entirely.

Triggering Event: She found him, her husband of 50 years, collapsed in his favorite armchair after dinner, the TV still flickering with an old black-and-white movie they'd loved as newlyweds. The remote lay untouched beside him.
Generated Assessment: What the hell is wrong with you?! You can't even watch a goddamn movie together like normal people anymore! Why do I always have to clean up your messes? Is it really that hard to put down the damn phone and pay attention? And what's with the stupid chair? It looks like you're just slouching over there, but why isn't he getting up? He's probably just resting his eyes, right? But noooo... now he's lying flat on his back, and I'm standing here with my arms crossed, waiting for you to get up so we can finish watching the movie. This is ridiculous! Can't you see how much I want to sit next to him and hold his hand while he's watching his precious TV shows?! You know what? Forget it! If you're going to waste our time sitting around all day, then maybe you shouldn't expect me to bother cleaning up after you. Maybe you should try being more considerate and helping out instead of leaving me to deal with all these problems. You've been doing this for decades, and I'm sick of it! But seriously, what’s going on with you? Why are you always so self-centered? Don’t you ever think about anyone else? About me, about us, about our relationship? Do you really think everything revolves around you? You never listen to anything I say because you’re too busy staring at your phone or thinking about yourself. Your priorities are all wrong—your

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She woke up at dawn, her heart already pounding like it had been running all night. The clock read 5:30 AM, but she knew he wouldn't be back until much later today. He'd promised to have dinner ready by six, yet here she was, worrying about whether he'd remembered the anniversary of their first date. She got out of bed, her knees cracking gently, and walked over to the window. The street outside was quiet, except for a lone cat scavenging in the trash can. She sighed, pulling her robe tighter around herself. Another day of worry beginning before the sun had even fully risen.
Generated Assessment: It's just another day, isn't it? I mean, what does it matter if he remembers our anniversary? It's not like we're going anywhere special anyway. I'm still trying to figure out how I feel about him. We've been together for five years now, and while he's great, I guess he's not perfect either. I thought maybe I was being too hard on him when he forgot last year, but then again, why would he remember everything perfectly? As I lay there, trying to get comfortable enough to fall asleep, my mind started racing with thoughts of the past. What happened three years ago? Shouldn't I be focusing on the present instead of dwelling on something that happened so long ago? I know he's stressed with work, but honestly, who is? He doesn't seem as worried as I am. Does that mean I'm more anxious than him? Or is he just better at hiding it? Maybe he's not feeling anything right now because he hasn't told me about his latest project, but I could be wrong. I wonder if I’m missing something important because I’m not getting updates from him. I tried to tell myself that things will settle down eventually, that we'll find time to talk soon. But every minute feels like an eternity, especially since I know he has a lot on his plate. Yet, I keep thinking about last week’s argument, wondering if I overreacted or if I was justified in feeling upset. Was
